BIOS220
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Students will develop an understanding of comparative anatomy and appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lecture sessions, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and scenario based discussions framed around pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These methods engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios.

Assessment will include:

A written communication to take the form of (for example, but not limited to) an advice leaflet or poster for an owner or producer relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will have a choice of species/topic, allowing them to pursue their area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

A written exam: This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and essay type questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, including the use of case based scenarios to ensure authentic assessment. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)
Educational Aims
1) Develop knowledge and understanding of the anatomy and physiology of key body systems, including a recognition of key species differences

2) Enable application of knowledge of normal functional anatomy to understand how disruption of these systems can lead to reduced productivity and disease.

3) Describe appropriate husbandry for a number of domesticated species, including livestock, pets and laboratory/minority farmed species, considering impacts on health, welfare and behaviour.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Through the use of lecture and case based learning, students will develop knowledge of comparative anatomy and physiology, and apply this knowledge to understand appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios during workshop and tutorial sessions.

Assessment will take the form of a written communication (advice for an owner or producer) based on a husbandry related topic of the students choice and a written exam to allow students to demonstrate and apply their knowledge of anatomy, physiology and animal husbandry.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory anatomy and physiology:
● Structure and function of the major body systems (locomotor, reproductive, digestive, cardiovascular/respiratory)
● Physiology relevant to health and welfare
● Comparative anatomy of major body systems (locomotor/digestive/reproductive)

Animal husbandry:
● Introduction to animal husbandry – role in animal health, welfare and productivity
● Species specific husbandry – including breed recognition and appropriate breed choice in production animals, typical production cycles and management practices in the UK, housing, feeding, reproduction, appropriate handling and behavioural considerations.
● Welfare – behaviour relevant to addressing problems associated with welfare of captive animals; The five freedoms/need and other relevant legislation and application of this in assessing husbandry practices.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching methods will include lectures and case based workshops and tutorials. Practical activities will complement the taught material, and may include but not be limited to, farm visits and anatomy practical sessions. Delivery methods may include, but are not limited to, flipped classrooms, polling, and case based discussions framed around pre-session reading or recordings. Attendance in person at taught sessions (A total of 30 hours contact time averaging approx. 3 hours per week) is expected and will be recorded. Independent learning through self directed and guided study makes up the remaining 120 hours of the module.

The variety of delivery methods allows for application of the Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks in all aspects of the module, and will develop students as active learners and producers of knowledge through research connected teaching. Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Appropriate use of learning technologies will develop digital fluency.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Written communication:

Student will produce advice for an owner or producer on an animal husbandry related topic – this may take the form of (for example) an advice leaflet or poster, suitable for an experienced animal caregiver, relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will be able to choose the most appropriate delivery method for their chosen topic. Providing choice ensures inclusivity and encourages development of effective written communication skills. An assessment rubric outlining the assessment requirements will be provided so that parity across different delivery methods can be ensured. This ensures a clear outline of requirements and transparency of marking. Students will be able to choose from a range of suggested topics, or suggest their own following discussion with the module team, allowing them to pursue any particular area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

Written exam:

1hr 30 minute in person exam. This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and case based long answer questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. The exact number and format of questions is to be confirmed but will follow School of Biosciences guidelines. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, and may include production data for analysis. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)

Formative assessment and feedback is provided informally during teaching sessions through the use of (including but not limited too) in class MCQ’s, polling software, discussions.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topics and/or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Describe structure and function of major body systems – including digestive, reproductive, locomotor and cardiovascular/respiratory.
 LO2 Apply knowledge of anatomy to discuss species specific differences which may affect health and performance.
 LO3 Describe and evaluate appropriate animal husbandry practices for a range of species.
 LO4 Explain how husbandry practices may impact on productivity, behaviour and welfare of a range of species.
Skills

Skills

Reassessment will use the same format but the topics and/or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Students will develop an understanding of comparative anatomy and appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lecture sessions, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and scenario based discussions framed around pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These methods engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios.

Assessment will include:

A written communication to take the form of (for example, but not limited to) an advice leaflet or poster for an owner or producer relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will have a choice of species/topic, allowing them to pursue their area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

A written exam: This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and essay type questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, including the use of case based scenarios to ensure authentic assessment. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)
Educational Aims
1) Develop knowledge and understanding of the anatomy and physiology of key body systems, including a recognition of key species differences

2) Enable application of knowledge of normal functional anatomy to understand how disruption of these systems can lead to reduced productivity and disease.

3) Describe appropriate husbandry for a number of domesticated species, including livestock, pets and laboratory/minority farmed species, considering impacts on health, welfare and behaviour.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Through the use of lecture and case based learning, students will develop knowledge of comparative anatomy and physiology, and apply this knowledge to understand appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios during workshop and tutorial sessions.

Assessment will take the form of a written communication (advice for an owner or producer) based on a husbandry related topic of the students choice and a written exam to allow students to demonstrate and apply their knowledge of anatomy, physiology and animal husbandry.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory anatomy and physiology:
● Structure and function of the major body systems (locomotor, reproductive, digestive, cardiovascular/respiratory)
● Physiology relevant to health and welfare
● Comparative anatomy of major body systems (locomotor/digestive/reproductive)

Animal husbandry:
● Introduction to animal husbandry – role in animal health, welfare and productivity
● Species specific husbandry – including breed recognition and appropriate breed choice in production animals, typical production cycles and management practices in the UK, housing, feeding, reproduction, appropriate handling and behavioural considerations.
● Welfare – behaviour relevant to addressing problems associated with welfare of captive animals; The five freedoms/need and other relevant legislation and application of this in assessing husbandry practices.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching methods will include lectures and case based workshops and tutorials. Practical activities will complement the taught material, and may include but not be limited to, farm visits and anatomy practical sessions. Delivery methods may include, but are not limited to, flipped classrooms, polling, and case based discussions framed around pre-session reading or recordings. Attendance in person at taught sessions (A total of 30 hours contact time averaging approx. 3 hours per week) is expected and will be recorded. Independent learning through self directed and guided study makes up the remaining 120 hours of the module.

The variety of delivery methods allows for application of the Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks in all aspects of the module, and will develop students as active learners and producers of knowledge through research connected teaching. Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Appropriate use of learning technologies will develop digital fluency.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Written communication:

Student will produce advice for an owner or producer on an animal husbandry related topic – this may take the form of (for example) an advice leaflet or poster, suitable for an experienced animal caregiver, relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will be able to choose the most appropriate delivery method for their chosen topic. Providing choice ensures inclusivity and encourages development of effective written communication skills. An assessment rubric outlining the assessment requirements will be provided so that parity across different delivery methods can be ensured. This ensures a clear outline of requirements and transparency of marking. Students will be able to choose from a range of suggested topics, or suggest their own following discussion with the module team, allowing them to pursue any particular area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

Written exam:

1hr 30 minute in person exam. This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and case based long answer questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. The exact number and format of questions is to be confirmed but will follow School of Biosciences guidelines. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, and may include production data for analysis. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)

Formative assessment and feedback is provided informally during teaching sessions through the use of (including but not limited too) in class MCQ’s, polling software, discussions.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topics and/or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS220
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Students will develop an understanding of comparative anatomy and appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lecture sessions, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and scenario based discussions framed around pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These methods engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios.

Assessment will include:

A written communication to take the form of (for example, but not limited to) an advice leaflet or poster for an owner or producer relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will have a choice of species/topic, allowing them to pursue their area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

A written exam: This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and essay type questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, including the use of case based scenarios to ensure authentic assessment. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)
Educational Aims
1) Develop knowledge and understanding of the anatomy and physiology of key body systems, including a recognition of key species differences

2) Enable application of knowledge of normal functional anatomy to understand how disruption of these systems can lead to reduced productivity and disease.

3) Describe appropriate husbandry for a number of domesticated species, including livestock, pets and laboratory/minority farmed species, considering impacts on health, welfare and behaviour.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Through the use of lecture and case based learning, students will develop knowledge of comparative anatomy and physiology, and apply this knowledge to understand appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios during workshop and tutorial sessions.

Assessment will take the form of a written communication (advice for an owner or producer) based on a husbandry related topic of the students choice and a written exam to allow students to demonstrate and apply their knowledge of anatomy, physiology and animal husbandry.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory anatomy and physiology:
● Structure and function of the major body systems (locomotor, reproductive, digestive, cardiovascular/respiratory)
● Physiology relevant to health and welfare
● Comparative anatomy of major body systems (locomotor/digestive/reproductive)

Animal husbandry:
● Introduction to animal husbandry – role in animal health, welfare and productivity
● Species specific husbandry – including breed recognition and appropriate breed choice in production animals, typical production cycles and management practices in the UK, housing, feeding, reproduction, appropriate handling and behavioural considerations.
● Welfare – behaviour relevant to addressing problems associated with welfare of captive animals; The five freedoms/need and other relevant legislation and application of this in assessing husbandry practices.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching methods will include lectures and case based workshops and tutorials. Practical activities will complement the taught material, and may include but not be limited to, farm visits and anatomy practical sessions. Delivery methods may include, but are not limited to, flipped classrooms, polling, and case based discussions framed around pre-session reading or recordings. Attendance in person at taught sessions (A total of 30 hours contact time averaging approx. 3 hours per week) is expected and will be recorded. Independent learning through self directed and guided study makes up the remaining 120 hours of the module.

The variety of delivery methods allows for application of the Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks in all aspects of the module, and will develop students as active learners and producers of knowledge through research connected teaching. Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Appropriate use of learning technologies will develop digital fluency.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Written communication:

Student will produce advice for an owner or producer on an animal husbandry related topic – this may take the form of (for example) an advice leaflet or poster, suitable for an experienced animal caregiver, relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will be able to choose the most appropriate delivery method for their chosen topic. Providing choice ensures inclusivity and encourages development of effective written communication skills. An assessment rubric outlining the assessment requirements will be provided so that parity across different delivery methods can be ensured. This ensures a clear outline of requirements and transparency of marking. Students will be able to choose from a range of suggested topics, or suggest their own following discussion with the module team, allowing them to pursue any particular area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

Written exam:

1hr 30 minute in person exam. This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and case based long answer questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. The exact number and format of questions is to be confirmed but will follow School of Biosciences guidelines. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, and may include production data for analysis. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)

Formative assessment and feedback is provided informally during teaching sessions through the use of (including but not limited too) in class MCQ’s, polling software, discussions.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topics and/or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Students will develop an understanding of comparative anatomy and appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lecture sessions, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and scenario based discussions framed around pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These methods engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios.

Assessment will include:

A written communication to take the form of (for example, but not limited to) an advice leaflet or poster for an owner or producer relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will have a choice of species/topic, allowing them to pursue their area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

A written exam: This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and essay type questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, including the use of case based scenarios to ensure authentic assessment. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)
Educational Aims
1) Develop knowledge and understanding of the anatomy and physiology of key body systems, including a recognition of key species differences

2) Enable application of knowledge of normal functional anatomy to understand how disruption of these systems can lead to reduced productivity and disease.

3) Describe appropriate husbandry for a number of domesticated species, including livestock, pets and laboratory/minority farmed species, considering impacts on health, welfare and behaviour.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will equip students with a working knowledge of animal form and function and develop their ability to critically examine the ways in which this might influence the productivity, health and welfare of domestic species. Through the use of lecture and case based learning, students will develop knowledge of comparative anatomy and physiology, and apply this knowledge to understand appropriate husbandry of domestic species (production animals, pets and laboratory species) including appropriate breed choices, behaviour, housing, management, diet and reproduction.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures, case based workshops and tutorials, and will include the opportunity for practical animal husbandry or anatomy based sessions where applicable. Opportunities for self testing and formative feedback will be embedded within the taught sessions. Students will develop communication skills and commercial awareness through small group work and the use of industry based husbandry scenarios during workshop and tutorial sessions.

Assessment will take the form of a written communication (advice for an owner or producer) based on a husbandry related topic of the students choice and a written exam to allow students to demonstrate and apply their knowledge of anatomy, physiology and animal husbandry.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory anatomy and physiology:
● Structure and function of the major body systems (locomotor, reproductive, digestive, cardiovascular/respiratory)
● Physiology relevant to health and welfare
● Comparative anatomy of major body systems (locomotor/digestive/reproductive)

Animal husbandry:
● Introduction to animal husbandry – role in animal health, welfare and productivity
● Species specific husbandry – including breed recognition and appropriate breed choice in production animals, typical production cycles and management practices in the UK, housing, feeding, reproduction, appropriate handling and behavioural considerations.
● Welfare – behaviour relevant to addressing problems associated with welfare of captive animals; The five freedoms/need and other relevant legislation and application of this in assessing husbandry practices.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching methods will include lectures and case based workshops and tutorials. Practical activities will complement the taught material, and may include but not be limited to, farm visits and anatomy practical sessions. Delivery methods may include, but are not limited to, flipped classrooms, polling, and case based discussions framed around pre-session reading or recordings. Attendance in person at taught sessions (A total of 30 hours contact time averaging approx. 3 hours per week) is expected and will be recorded. Independent learning through self directed and guided study makes up the remaining 120 hours of the module.

The variety of delivery methods allows for application of the Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks in all aspects of the module, and will develop students as active learners and producers of knowledge through research connected teaching. Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Appropriate use of learning technologies will develop digital fluency.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Written communication:

Student will produce advice for an owner or producer on an animal husbandry related topic – this may take the form of (for example) an advice leaflet or poster, suitable for an experienced animal caregiver, relating to an appropriate area of animal husbandry practice. Students will be able to choose the most appropriate delivery method for their chosen topic. Providing choice ensures inclusivity and encourages development of effective written communication skills. An assessment rubric outlining the assessment requirements will be provided so that parity across different delivery methods can be ensured. This ensures a clear outline of requirements and transparency of marking. Students will be able to choose from a range of suggested topics, or suggest their own following discussion with the module team, allowing them to pursue any particular area of interest and ensuring inclusivity. This is an authentic form of assessment allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply knowledge to a real world scenario, and to produce a piece of work which reflects their engagement with the subject. (Liverpool Curriculum framework hallmarks: Inclusivity; Confidence; Digital Fluency; Active Learning; Research-connected teaching; Authentic assessment)

Written exam:

1hr 30 minute in person exam. This will include a variety of question types, including short answer and case based long answer questions allowing students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes. The exact number and format of questions is to be confirmed but will follow School of Biosciences guidelines. Questions will be constructed to allow demonstration and integrated application of knowledge, and may include production data for analysis. (Liverpool curriculum framework hallmarks: Authentic assessment; Active learning; Confidence)

Formative assessment and feedback is provided informally during teaching sessions through the use of (including but not limited too) in class MCQ’s, polling software, discussions.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topics and/or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
